javadoc:
Class for managing the creation of some slow loading object that may be used by multiple threads, including the Swing thread. Further, repeated calls to this object will used the cached value.

The basic uses cases are:

  1. Call {@link #get(TaskMonitor)} from the Swing thread - this will block the Swing thread, showing a modal dialog, as needed.
  2. Call {@link #get(TaskMonitor)} from a non-Swing thread - this will block the calling thread, with no effect on the UI.
  3. Call {@link #startLoading()} - this will trigger this worker to load in the background without blocking the calling thread.
  4. Call {@link #getCachedValue()} - this is a way to see if the value has been loaded without blocking the current thread.
  5. Override {@link #done()} - this method will be called when the initial loading is finished.

methods.name: <init>

params.name: name
params.comment: the name of worker. (Displayed in the progress dialog)

params.name: hasProgress
params.comment: true if the dialog should show progress or be indeterminate.

methods.javadoc:
Sets the initial delay before showing a progress dialog.  The default is 100ms.
@param delay the delay to wait before displaying a progress dialog.
methods.name: setTaskDialogDelay
methods.comment: Sets the initial delay before showing a progress dialog.  The default is 100ms.

params.name: delay
params.comment: the delay to wait before displaying a progress dialog.

methods.javadoc:
Subclasses must implement this method to create the object being managed/cached.
@param monitor A task monitor that can be used to provide progress information to
 a progress dialog is it is being shown.  Implementers should also check the monitor 
 periodically to check for cancelled. If cancelled, this method should not throw a
 cancelled exception but instead either return null or a partial result. (For example,
 if the object is a list being generated by a search, then it might make sense to return
 a list of the items found so far.)
@return the newly created object.
methods.name: runInBackground
methods.comment: Subclasses must implement this method to create the object being managed/cached.

params.name: monitor
params.comment:
A task monitor that can be used to provide progress information to
 a progress dialog is it is being shown.  Implementers should also check the monitor 
 periodically to check for cancelled. If cancelled, this method should not throw a
 cancelled exception but instead either return null or a partial result. (For example,
 if the object is a list being generated by a search, then it might make sense to return
 a list of the items found so far.)

methods.name: get
methods.comment:
Returns the object that this class is managing/caching.  It will return the object if it is
 already created or it will block until the object can be created.  If called from the Swing 
 thread, it will also launch a modal progress dialog while waiting for the object to be
 created.

return.comment: the object that this class is managing/caching

methods.javadoc: Allows clients to start this worker loading without blocking.
methods.name: startLoading
methods.comment: Allows clients to start this worker loading without blocking.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the value only if it is cached, otherwise return null.
@return the value only if it is cached, otherwise return null.
methods.name: getCachedValue
methods.comment: Returns the value only if it is cached, otherwise return null.

return.comment: the value only if it is cached, otherwise return null.

methods.javadoc: Clears the cached value for the object causing it to be recreated on the next call to get()
methods.name: clear
methods.comment: Clears the cached value for the object causing it to be recreated on the next call to get()

methods.javadoc:
A method for clients to use as a callback for completion.  This method will be called in
 the Swing thread, after the value has been set.
methods.name: done
methods.comment:
A method for clients to use as a callback for completion.  This method will be called in
 the Swing thread, after the value has been set.

name: CachingSwingWorker
comment:
Class for managing the creation of some slow loading object that may be used by multiple threads,
 including the Swing thread.  Further, repeated calls to this object will used the
 cached value.
 
 The basic uses cases are:
 
 	
 		Call #get(TaskMonitor) from the Swing thread - this will block the Swing thread,
      showing a modal dialog, as needed.
  
  
  	Call #get(TaskMonitor) from a non-Swing thread - this will block the calling
      thread, with no effect on the UI.
  
  Call #startLoading() - this will trigger this worker to load in the background
      without blocking the calling thread.
  
  
  	Call #getCachedValue() - this is a way to see if the value has been loaded
      without blocking the current thread.
  
  
  	Override #done() - this method will be called when the initial loading
      is finished.
